awd_abstract_narration:
A free neutron is unstable and decays via the weak interaction into a proton, electron, and antineutrino with a mean lifetime of about 15 minutes. By measuring the energies and directions of the emitted particles and the neutron spin, details of the underlying interaction are revealed.  We pass a beam of cold neutrons (moving less than 2000 m/s) through apparatus designed to make precise measurements of the neutron decay lifetime and angular correlations. Beause neutron decay is a relatively simple system, absent the complications of nuclear wave functions, these observables are related to fundamental theoretical parameters directly and unambiguously. We use these results to test predictions of the Standard Electroweak Model and search for evidence of new physics such as scalar/tensor forces or new CP-violation. The precise value of the neutron lifetime is needed to calculate the primordial abundances of light elements produced in the early universe from Big Bang nucleosynthesis.

The neutron is a key building block of ordinary matter. When freed from the confines of an atom, the neutron is unstable and will decay into other elementary particles: a proton, an electron, and a lightweight neutral particle called an antineutrino. Neutron decay is a useful laboratory for studying details of the force responsible - the weak nuclear force - one of the four fundamental forces of nature. We pass a beam of free neutrons through specialized detectors that precisely measure the neutron decay rate and the angles between the emitted particles. From this we can test and refine our theory of the weak nuclear force and better understand the physics of the sun, stars, the Big Bang, and important nuclear reactions.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

This award, entitled "Precision Neutron Decay Measurements" supported a program of experimental research on free neutron beta decay. The neutron, proton, and electron are the elementary particles that form atoms and comprise ordinary matter. But when freed from the confines of a stable atomic nucleus, the neutron becomes unstable and decays into a proton, electron, and antineutrino with an average lifetime of about 800 seconds. The weak nuclear force, one of the four fundamental forces of nature, is responsible for this. By studying the details of this process, such the angular correlations between the emitted particles, we can improve our understanding of the weak force and gain insight into more fundamental physics such as a possible Grand Unified Theory. Neutron decay was an important process in the early universe; it strongly influenced the formation of light elements during the first five minutes following the Big Bang.

My research group, along with collaborators at other universities and national laboratories, has designed, constructed, and operated a variety of instruments that make precision measurements of neutron decay observables. Most of these collect data at the NIST Center for Neutron Research (NCNR) in Gaithersburg, Maryland, one of the premier sources of cold neutron beams in the world. Specific accomplishments during the three-year period of this award included:

1) Final analysis and publication of results from the emiT experiment, which measures a particular three-fold angular correlation between the neutron spin direction (clockwise or counterclockwise) and its decay electron and proton, were completed. This correlation, known as the D-coefficient, is expected to be very close to zero. A large value could be associated with a violation of CP symmetry, a mirror-like symmetry between particles and antiparticles, that would have profound effects on our understanding of particle physics. The experiment found that the D-coefficient is less than about 0.3% and consistent with zero.

2) The aCORN instrument was completed, commissioned, and collected data in 2013-2014. It measures the "a coefficient", the angular correlation between the neutron decay electron and antineutrino. It provides useful information about the geometric symmetries of the weak force. We announced the first result in November 2015: a = -0.106, consistent with previous experiments but more precise. aCORN has since been relocated to a more intense neutron beam at the NCNR for a higher precision run that is currently in progress.

3) The RDK II experiment was completed and a result obtained. This experiment detects a rare form of neutron decay where an energetic photon (particle of light) is also emitted when the neutron decays. We detected thousands of these radiative neutron decays and made a precise measurement of their probability: 0.33% when the photon energy is at least 14,000 electron-volts.

Broader Impacts:

Two graduate students and one postdoctoral fellow were supported by this award and received extensive scientific training while working on these experiments. They learned the techniques and methodology of proton and electron detection, detector electronics, vacuum systems, cryogenics, neutron beam transport and characterization, precision mechanical design and alignment, and data acquisition and analysis. They can use this knowledge base and skill set in future careers either in academic science or industry.
